The lex Furia testamentaria, tue 183, imposed a penalty os four times the excess upon any one (except the cognates ol the person by whom the testator had been manumitted or emancipated‚ Ulpian‚ reg. 28. 7), who took as a legacy, or mortis causa, more than 1000 asses from the same person: itis remarkable lor being the first' enactment ol the civil law relating to inheritance in which cognatio is recognised as a title. As Gaius remarks, it altogether sailed in its object, ‘qui enim verbi gratia quinque millium aeris patrimonium habebat, poterat quinque hominibus singulis millenos asses legando totum patrimonium erogare' · ii. 225. The lex Voconia, tat: 169 (Cic. pro Balbo 8, in Verr. 2. 1. 42, 43, de senect. 5, defin. 2. 17, de repub. 3. 10), which Gaius regards as an attempt to provide a more effectual remedy against intestacy‚ seems really to have been only a relaxation ol the lex Furia in favour of wealthy testatore ; any person ranked in the first class ol the census as owner os 100,000 sesterces or upwards (Cic. in Verr. loc. cit.) might bequeath away as much as he pleased‚ provided no legacy or gift mortis causa exceeded in amount the share which the heir (or each ol two or more co-heirs) received himself. Both statutes were superseded by the lex Falcidia, uc. 40, the terms os which ran as follows, ‘quicunque civis Romanus posthanc legem rogatam testamentum saciet, is quantum cuique civi Romano pecuniam iure publico dare legare volet, ius po- testasque esto, dum iradetur legatum, ne minus quam partem quartam hereditatis eo testamento heredes capiant’ Dig. 35. 2. 1. pr.
